message_1: In a game, there are two piles of stones with 5 and 8 stones respectively. Players take turns removing any positive integer amount of stones from one pile. The player who removes the last stone wins. If both players play optimally, who will win the game?
message_2:
To determine the winner, we can use the strategy of Nim, a mathematical game theory. In Nim, the winning strategy is based on the binary digital sum (XOR) of the sizes of the piles. If the XOR of the pile sizes is non-zero, the first player has a winning strategy; otherwise, the second player has a winning strategy.

In this case, we have two piles with 5 and 8 stones. The binary representation of 5 is 101, and the binary representation of 8 is 1000. To find the XOR, we align the numbers and perform the XOR operation:

  0101 (5)
  1000 (8)
  ----
  1101 (13)

Since the XOR result is non-zero (13), the first player has a winning strategy. Therefore, if both players play optimally, the first player will win the game.
